title: Application: Ready To Act: Embodying Christ in the Digital Age

content.instructions:
Let's break down the practical applications into three sections, focusing on resource utilization, coordination, and ecumenical efforts:

For the Individual:

Personal Audit: Conduct a "digital discipleship" audit of your own tech habits and skills. Identify areas where you can better align your digital life with your faith.  
Skill Sharing: Offer your tech skills to your local church or faith community. This could involve helping with website design, social media management, or digital literacy classes for seniors.  
Interfaith Dialogue: Engage in online interfaith dialogues about technology ethics, seeking to understand diverse perspectives while sharing your Christ-centered approach.  
Continuous Learning: Commit to ongoing education about the intersection of faith and technology. Follow Christian tech blogs, attend webinars, or join online study groups.  
Digital Sabbath: Implement a regular "digital Sabbath" to model healthy tech habits and deepen your spiritual practices.

For Our Church:

Tech Stewardship Team: Establish a "Technology Stewardship" team in your church to assess and guide the congregation's use of technology.  
Resource Mapping: Create a database of tech skills within your congregation. Use this to match needs with abilities, reducing reliance on external, often costly, services.  
Digital Missions: Develop a "digital missions" strategy, using technology to extend your church's outreach and support global partners more efficiently.  
Ethical Tech Policy: Draft a church-wide ethical technology use policy, grounded in biblical principles and humane tech concepts.  
Intergenerational Mentoring: Pair tech-savvy youth with older members for mutual learning \- tech skills exchanged for life wisdom.  
Open-Source Ministry Resources: Commit to creating and sharing open-source ministry resources (like curriculum or management tools) with other churches.

For Ecumenical Gatherings:

Ecumenical Tech Summits: Organize or participate in regular ecumenical "Faith and Technology" summits, bringing together diverse Christian traditions to address common challenges.  
Shared Resource Platform: Develop a cross-denominational online platform for sharing tech resources, best practices, and case studies of successful digital ministry initiatives.  
United Advocacy: Form an ecumenical coalition to advocate for ethical tech policies at local and national levels, presenting a united Christian voice on issues like data privacy, AI ethics, and digital equality.  
Collaborative Innovation: Establish an ecumenical "Christian Innovation Lab" where technologists from various traditions can collaborate on projects that serve the broader Body of Christ.  
Interfaith Tech Ethics Council: Initiate or join an interfaith council on technology ethics, bringing Christian perspectives into dialogue with other faith traditions on pressing tech issues.  
Global Digital Missions Coordination: Create a coordination body for global digital missions efforts to prevent duplication and enhance collaboration across denominations.  
Ecumenical Digital Literacy Program: Develop a comprehensive digital literacy program that can be adapted and used across different Christian traditions, especially serving underprivileged communities.

By focusing on these areas, we can better steward our resources, foster unity in the body of Christ, and present a more coherent Christian witness in the face of exponential technological change. This approach acknowledges our common ground in Christ while respecting denominational differences, and positions the Church to be a leading voice in shaping a more humane technological future.
